awd_titl_txt: Characterization of Biomolecular Response to Environmental Stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Platinum group elements derived from automobile catalytic converters have increased in roadside soil, plants, and air. However, little is known about the mechanism of platinum group elements toxicity and its impact on living organisms. With National Science Foundation support, Texas Southern University will initiate a research program that integrates systems biology, genomics, proteomics, and bio-informatics approaches to develop computer models capable of characterizing stress responses in eukaryotic cells as well as understand how environmental toxicants impact bacterial members of the gut microbiota. The project will employ a multidisciplinary team to educate graduate, undergraduate, and rising high school students, expand and strengthen the existing Ph.D. program in Environmental Toxicology, facilitate the professional development of junior faculty, and enhance the institution's research infrastructure.

Intellectual Merit:  
The proposed activity will contribute to the current knowledge of environmental exposure to patinum group elements and vanadium and associated biomolecular effects and potential health risks. An array of new technologies and innovative approaches in molecular biology, nanotechnology, and computer modeling will be employed to assess exposure to patinum group elements and vanadium, and study environmental stress responses in eukaryotic cells and gut microbiota. The proposed research will (1) assess the exposure to platinum group elements and vanadium in nano-size atmospheric particulate matter and associated health risk, (2) examine the effect of platinum group elements and vanadium on transcription factors, MAP kinases and pro-inflammatory cytokines in human lung epithelial cells and use computer models to predict  the pathways and characterize various responses to platinum group elements in eukaryotic cells, and (3) characterize platinum group elements and vanadium exposure to representative prokaryotic members of the gut microbiota and develop a microbial biosensor for human disease.

Broader Impacts:
The results of this investigation will be employed to develop predictive computer models for biomolecular pathways involved and advanced potential risk prediction tools that can help environmental quality managers make informed decisions in developing more efficient management strategies. In addition, by examining common affected pathways in microbes and eukaryotic cells, simple biological biosensors may be developed for the assessment of the effects of these pollutants on humans. The project combines education and research efforts to prepare high-caliber doctoral scientists in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics related fields by strengthening and expanding the existing Ph.D. program in Environmental Toxicology. By training African-American and other minority undergraduate and graduate students in emerging areas of environmental biology, biomaterials science, bio-engineering, and synthetic biology, the institution will continue to increase the numbers of well-prepared minority professionals engaged in research, teaching, and management, and develop the  STEM workforce. Project activities will strengthen the institution's research infrastructure and promote innovative partnerships within scientific communities, enhance basic biology research, technology development/transfers and commercialization.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Infrastructure in Science and Engineering (RISE) project, Characterization of Biomolecular Response to Environmental Stress, was a multidisciplinary effort that involved collaboration among a microbiologist (Rosenzweig), a physicist (Vrinceanu), an environmental chemist (Hwang), and a eukaryotic cell biologist (Shishodia). The funding was truly transformative allowing us to purchase equipment, research supplies, and conduct student training. The grant enhanced research infrastructure (through both NSF and institutional matching funds) via the purchase of a state-of-the-art near-infrared imaging system (for proteins and nucleic acids), an ultra-deep freezer, an automated microplate reader, a semi-automated DNA/RNA extractor, a Biolog microstation for unknown bacterial isolate identification, a fluorescence microscope, a quantitative PCR thermocycler, high-volume particulate matter samplers, and atmospheric deposition samplers for air pollutant collection.

Beyond enhancing our research infrastructure, the RISE award enabled us to train 14 high school students in addition to 16 undergraduate research scholars during our summer outreach activities. These underrepresented (as defined by NSF) student participants gained valuable training through training programs, research seminars, journal club participation, and bench work guided by program graduate students (MS and PhD) through our vertically aligned training model that has been published in the peer-reviewed American Biology Teacher journal. Summer participants often sought to maintain research relationships with the various PI’s labs and would often continue their training during the winter break and subsequent summers. Four students in the program have graduated with  Ph.D. degree,  and 8 students in the program graduated with Master degrees. Ten graduate students, currently in the program, are expected to graduate in the Fall 2020/Spring 2021 academic year. 

Students preformed many research projects, including source apportionment of trace metals in highway road dust, source apportionment of fine sediment particles in roadway stormwater runoff, quantification of lead in tap water and its link to infrastructure construction year, contribution of tires to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in highway dust, and relationship between trace metal pollution in surface soil and socioeconomic status. Further, our studies expanded our knowledge about how lung cells, gut cells, and bacteria respond to dust and dust components (including platinum group metals). Additionally, we evaluated how bacteria respond to dust in both mixed and pure bacterial cultures. Finally, we modeled the gut environment by studying bacterial-eukaryotic cell gut co-culture environments.

Our project’s research findings have led to the publication of 35 peer-reviewed journal articles, and more than 80 oral and poster presentations given at local, regional, national, and international conferences and professional meetings. Students that participated at these meetings interacted with scientists, engineers, government officers, and experts in private sectors to build networks for future collaboration and/or professional employment. Several students received awards for best oral/poster presentations. In April 2017, we hosted the South-Central Regional Meeting of the Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry. Every year, we organized a one-day Research Colloquium open to our Texas Southern University community of researchers.

Some data from these projects have already been adopted to implement more efficient road surface management actions. Other data are also expected to help develop new environmental regulations or amend existing regulations. Students learned many critical skills, techniques, and strategies for environmental sample collection, laboratory chemical analysis, human health risk assessment, statistical analysis, and data interpretation. Students were trained to use state-of-the art analytical instrumentation such as inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) and gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC-MS).
